subs.text: April 4
It is possible that I saw the Gumby episode cited here when it first aired. I was four at the time and I loved Gumby. [link]
subs.rawText: It is possible that I saw the Gumby episode cited here when it first aired. I was four at the time and I loved Gumby. https://t.co/bqiFaCojGy

subs.text: If so, it might had been my first exposure to typesetting equipment and computer keyboards. (My dad had a typewriter, and would occasionally bring home surplus  punch cards from his dissertation work, which was a FORTRAN linear programming project.)
subs.rawText: If so, it might had been my first exposure to typesetting equipment and computer keyboards. (My dad had a typewriter, and would occasionally bring home surplus  punch cards from his dissertation work, which was a FORTRAN linear programming project.)

subs.text: One wonders about the impact of shows watched and forgotten in childhood.

subs.text: @sevensixfive If God had wanted us to see the Columbian Exhibition, he would have had us be born in the 19th century. As was my great grandmother, who found the San Francisco earthquake more memorable than the subsequent exhibition.
subs.rawText: @sevensixfive If God had wanted us to see the Columbian Exhibition, he would have had us be born in the 19th century. As was my great grandmother, who found the San Francisco earthquake more memorable than the subsequent exhibition.

subs.text: @sevensixfive Since the earthquake likely contributed to her subsequent miscarriage, and thereby to the birth of my grandmother two years later, I ask that time travelers not interfere with early 20th century Californian plate tectonics.
subs.rawText: @sevensixfive Since the earthquake likely contributed to her subsequent miscarriage, and thereby to the birth of my grandmother two years later, I ask that time travelers not interfere with early 20th century Californian plate tectonics.

subs.text: @sevensixfive Thank you. [link]

subs.text: @AvBronstein Let me try a contrarian take. DSM defines mental disorders in large part by their interference with daily functioning. ADA requires that accommodation be given to holders of a DSM diagnosis. The result is a bureaucratic accommodation of extreme grief — which is a good thing.
subs.rawText: @AvBronstein Let me try a contrarian take. DSM defines mental disorders in large part by their interference with daily functioning. ADA requires that accommodation be given to holders of a DSM diagnosis. The result is a bureaucratic accommodation of extreme grief — which is a good thing.

subs.text: @AvBronstein And perhaps the best that can be asked for in a bureaucratic society.
subs.rawText: @AvBronstein And perhaps the best that can be asked for in a bureaucratic society.

subs.text: @AvBronstein Needless to say, that’s not the approach taken by the books I’ve published on the topic. [link]
subs.rawText: @AvBronstein Needless to say, that’s not the approach taken by the books I’ve published on the topic. https://t.co/cyk7l0Gt7F

subs.text: @christapeterso Rho might have discovered the counter on his own, as my Trooper did. Where he discovered a love for bread.
subs.rawText: @christapeterso Rho might have discovered the counter on his own, as my Trooper did. Where he discovered a love for bread.

subs.text: @christapeterso It was a live that transcended the plastic bags the bread came in. It was a love that transcended the bread box I bought to protect the bread from Trooper.
subs.rawText: @christapeterso It was a live that transcended the plastic bags the bread came in. It was a love that transcended the bread box I bought to protect the bread from Trooper.

subs.text: @christapeterso It was a love that figured out how to open the refrigerator when I began storing the bread there.
subs.rawText: @christapeterso It was a love that figured out how to open the refrigerator when I began storing the bread there.

subs.text: @christapeterso Fortunately, even Trooper’s love for bread could not transcend the wooden refrigerator guard my father built in his workshop. Which also cut down on my own refrigerator browsing.
subs.rawText: @christapeterso Fortunately, even Trooper’s love for bread could not transcend the wooden refrigerator guard my father built in his workshop. Which also cut down on my own refrigerator browsing.

subs.text: @christapeterso Trooper’s counter explorations then led him to discover the joy of tomatoes. Which led me to discover the pros and cons of refrigerating tomatoes.
subs.rawText: @christapeterso Trooper’s counter explorations then led him to discover the joy of tomatoes. Which led me to discover the pros and cons of refrigerating tomatoes.

subs.text: @Yair_Rosenberg I think you underestimate the challenges involved in asking her “at the outset to account for her anti-Semitic utterances. These questions should be posed in specific and concrete terms, making explicit reference to the ugly ideas she has written and recommended.”

subs.text: @Yair_Rosenberg Do you quote and then call @FoxmanAbraham for a rebuttal? And now you’ve both-sided the Protocols.

subs.text: @Yair_Rosenberg @FoxmanAbraham Do you simply say, Walker, who holds bizarre antisemitic conspiracy theories, as an appositive clause as if it were an honorary degree or a lingering illness?
subs.rawText: @Yair_Rosenberg @FoxmanAbraham Do you simply say, Walker, who holds bizarre antisemitic conspiracy theories, as an appositive clause as if it were an honorary degree or a lingering illness?

subs.text: @Yair_Rosenberg @FoxmanAbraham The journalistic conventions of approaching every main character with a presumption of good faith makes de facto cancellation the easiest course for a reporter and editor for whom an Alice Walker appearance is supposed to be an easy story.
subs.rawText: @Yair_Rosenberg @FoxmanAbraham The journalistic conventions of approaching every main character with a presumption of good faith makes de facto cancellation the easiest course for a reporter and editor for whom an Alice Walker appearance is supposed to be an easy story.
